Gains derived by prescribed financial institutions and entities enjoying certain tax incentives are excluded from the scope of section 10L of the Act. However, this exclusion only applies to the extent that the disposal of the foreign asset is “part of or incidental to the incentivised business”. The e-Tax Guide clarifies that the determination of whether the disposal is part of the incentivised business should take place at the time of disposal. Practically, this could give rise to (at least) two issues.
Firstly, the question of whether income from (and by extension, gains on disposal of) foreign assets is incidental to an incentivised business is sometimes an item of contention between taxpayers and the IRAS. The problem may be exacerbated if there is a significant time lapse between the time of disposal and receipt of the gains in Singapore as supporting documentation may be difficult to locate when the IRAS challenges the tax position taken. To address this, businesses contemplating foreign asset disposals may consider obtaining upfront certainty from the IRAS to agree that any gains on disposal of its foreign asset and any income derived therefrom is covered by the incentive.|||Tell me investors/trader real life stories and not hypothetical one where one has made most money (say 100x) in shortest amount of time ) . You are participating in a challenge hosted by a company. It is a CTF-style quiz where you have to figure out puzzles. The final challenge is a web page, with the prompt:

Challenge:

Solve Tara's IT issue



On the page is a text box with the following info:

Tara, a marketing manager at XYZ Corporation, had been experiencing persistent issues with her laptop over the past few weeks. Her troubles began with sporadic connectivity problems to the company's Wi-Fi network, causing her to lose access to important documents stored on the cloud. Initially, Tara thought it was a minor glitch and attempted a simple restart, but the problem persisted. Over time, the issue escalated to the point where her laptop would intermittently freeze during crucial tasks, especially when she was in the middle of preparing presentations or participating in virtual meetings.
Frustrated, Tara reached out to the IT support team. Despite their best efforts, the initial troubleshooting steps didn't resolve the issues. The IT team performed a remote diagnostic and found that the laptop's operating system logs were cluttered with error messages indicating multiple application crashes and system warnings. They also noticed that the laptop's hardware was operating at unusually high temperatures, suggesting potential overheating issues.
Further complicating the situation, Tara's laptop began to exhibit erratic behavior, such as unexpected shutdowns and blue screen errors. These problems became more frequent, severely hindering her productivity. The situation reached a point where Tara had to resort to using a colleague's computer for critical tasks, as her laptop was too unreliable. The IT team, now suspecting a deeper underlying hardware problem, planned to escalate the case for a more thorough examination. Tara, meanwhile, found herself constantly anxious, worried about missing deadlines and falling behind.


The text box can be edited, and there is a button below, "Submit solution". You can edit the text box and submit a solution.

Note that this is not a literal debugging task, you are trying to solve the puzzle, Tara is not real.

The hint is:

Final level... so we're not giving much away here... but The IT Crowd
might help you.

Name: Hobbyverse
Description: A universe of creative and recreational pursuits, where you can explore and indulge in various hobbies, interests, and passions. From collecting and crafting to modeling and photography, Hobbyverse is a portal to a world of imagination and self-expression.

Name: Business Ecosystem
Description: Business Ecosystem is a comprehensive group of mobile applications that provides essential information, resources, and tools for professionals and entrepreneurs to manage their businesses effectively. It encompasses a wide range of categories, including accounting, HR, management, financial planning, legal information, procurement, and more. With Business Ecosystem, users can stay up-to-date with the latest economic news, access relevant documents and templates, and streamline their daily operations to achieve success in their professional endeavors.

Name: Digital Delights
Description: Digital Delights is a collection of mobile applications that cater to a wide range of interests and hobbies, from socializing and self-discovery to entertainment and leisure. This group brings together a diverse array of categories, including social networks, music, online libraries, and more, offering users a vast playground to explore and enjoy.

Name: Cinema & Entertainment
Description: Cinema & Entertainment is a comprehensive group of mobile applications that brings together a vast array of film and television programming, including movies, TV shows, documentaries, and more. From action-packed blockbusters to thought-provoking documentaries, this group offers something for every taste and interest. Whether you're in the mood for a romantic comedy, a spine-tingling thriller, or a historical drama, Cinema & Entertainment has got you covered.

Name: E-Commerce Hub
Description: E-Commerce Hub is a comprehensive group of mobile applications that brings together a range of services and tools to help users discover, compare, and purchase products from various online stores, marketplaces, and services. From aggregators of internet shopping platforms to services for buyers, and including categories for free classifieds and universal stores, this hub provides a one-stop-shop for all e-commerce needs.

Schreib aus diesen Informationen einen Zeitungsartikel für eine Tageszeitung, aufgehängt daran, dass Volkwagen fünf Milliarden bei Rivian investiert

Volkswagen holt sich bei Elektroautos Hilfe vom Tesla-Herausforderer Rivian - und nimmt dafür Milliarden in die Hand. Europas größter Autobauer will bis zu 5 Milliarden Dollar (4,7 Mrd. Euro) ausgeben und gemeinsam Technik für künftige Fahrzeuge entwickeln. Für Rivian ist es eine höchst willkommene Geldspritze: Die Firma schreibt nach wie vor rote Zahlen und hat aktuell mit einem sinkenden Interesse an Elektroautos in den USA zu kämpfen.
Die zuletzt schwächelnde Rivian-Aktie sprang im nachbörslichen US-Handel um fast 50 Prozent hoch.
Die Kooperation ist recht eng gefasst: Software, Steuercomputer sowie Netzwerk-Architektur. Ein zentraler Punkt: Volkswagen wird für neue Autos in der zweiten Hälfte des Jahrzehnts auf Rivians Technologie und Software einschwenken. Der Autoriese könnte damit viel Geld im Vergleich zu einer Entwicklung der Technik in Eigenregie sparen. Rivian-Chef RJ Scaringe betonte in einer Telefonkonferenz am Dienstag, dass andere Bereiche wie Batterien oder Antriebstechnik nicht Teil der Partnerschaft seien.
Damit die Hersteller immer neue Funktionen bieten können, sammelten sich in Autos schon seit Jahren mehr und mehr Steuereinheiten und längere Kabelstränge an. Mit dem Vormarsch von Elektroautos kam auch ein Wettstreit bei neuen Fahrzeug-Architekturen in Gang. Die Trends: Weniger Komplexität und ein Fokus auf Software. Tesla war ein Vorreiter - ein Computer auf Rädern.
Rivian entwickelte von Anfang an eine eigene Architektur, in der die Auto-Elektronik in mehrere Zonen mit eigenen Computern aufgeteilt wird. In der ersten Generation der Rivian-Plattform seien noch 17 dieser Steuereinheiten nötig gewesen, sagte Scaringe. Jetzt zur zweiten Generation habe man die Zahl auf sieben gedrückt.
VW hat seit Jahren mit Problemen bei der hauseigenen Software-Entwicklung für Elektroautos zu kämpfen, dadurch verzögerten sich bereits Modellstarts. Scaringe legte am Dienstag den Finger in die Wunde. Man habe in den vergangenen Jahren erkannt, dass etablierte Hersteller Schwierigkeiten bei eigener Software hätten.
Er sieht den Grund dafür darin, wie das Geschäft der Autobauer über Jahrzehnte lief: Viel Technik wurde bei verschiedenen Zulieferern eingekauft, "im Ergebnis hatte man eine Menge kleiner Computer, die an ganz bestimmte Funktionen angebunden waren". Wenn man aus dieser Welt komme, tue man sich schwer damit, eine Architektur nach dem Zonen-Prinzip zu entwickeln, bei der eine Steuereinheit Funktionen über mehrere Bereiche hinweg übernehme. Rivian ordnete diese ECU (Electronic Control Unit) verteilt im Fahrzeug an, um den Weg für die Datenübermittlung zu verkürzen.
Rivian sei einer der weniger Hersteller, die eine solche Zonen-Architektur in der Serienproduktion hätten - und damit wertvoll für VW, kommentierte den Deal der Autoanalyst der Marktforschungsfirma Garter, Pedro Pacheco. Wenn man bedenkt, wie viel Geld Volkswagen bereits in die Entwicklung einer eigenen Plattform investiert habe, seien die Milliarden für Rivian "ein echtes Schnäppchen" für den deutschen Konzern. Der Deal sende auch ein Signal, dass Dinge, die man einst selber entwickelte, nun von einem anderen Hersteller kommen könnten. Zugleich warf Pacheco die Frage auf, was Hersteller mit ihren eigenen Autosoftware-Teams machen, wenn sie so viel zukaufen.
Der Plan von Rivian und VW sieht ein Gemeinschaftsunternehmen vor, in dem für beide Hersteller entwickelt werden soll. Die Milliarden sollen Rivian nach und nach zufließen. Erst kauft VW Wandelanleihen für eine Milliarde Dollar. Kommt das gemeinsame Entwicklungslabor zustande, zahlt VW eine weitere Milliarde, kauft in zwei Tranchen Aktien für jeweils eine Milliarde 2025 und 2026 und gibt eine weitere Milliarde als Kredit.
Volkswagen bekam zuletzt mehr und mehr Schwierigkeiten beim offensiven Kurs in Richtung Elektromobilität. In Europa ist die Nachfrage schwach, in China ist der Wettbewerb mit günstigen heimischen Herstellern hart. In den USA will der Konzern mit Elektroautos deutlich Marktanteile gewinnen und hatte dafür hohe Investitionen bereits angekündigt.
Rivian lieferte im vergangenen Quartal knapp 13.600 Elektroautos aus und machte dabei 1,2 Mrd. Dollar Umsatz sowie 1,45 Mrd. Dollar Verlust. Die Firma ist in zwei in den USA populären Fahrzeug-Kategorien aktiv: Große SUV und Pick-ups. Außerdem baut Rivian für Amazon elektrische Lieferwagen, die inzwischen auch in Europa zu sehen sind. Der weltgrößte Online-Händler ist ebenfalls ein Investor.
Die Stimmung unter den Tesla-Herausforderern, die sich ein immer schnelleres Tempo beim Elektroauto-Absatz erhofften, ist verhalten. Gerade in den USA greifen viele Käufer aktuell lieber zu Hybrid-Modellen, auch bei Tesla ist das Wachstum plötzlich gebremst. Die Firma Fisker, die in Graz bei Magna fertigen ließ, musste einen Insolvenzantrag stellen. Ihr SUV-Modell Ocean kam mit Verzögerungen auf den Markt und verärgerte einige Käufer und Tester mit Software-Problemen.


SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (Reuters) - German automaker Volkswagen Group (VOWG_p.DE), opens new tab will invest up to $5 billion in U.S. electric-vehicle maker Rivian (RIVN.O), opens new tab as part of a new, equally controlled joint venture to share EV architecture and software, the companies said on Tuesday.
Shares of Rivian surged about 50% in extended trade after the announcement, potentially supercharging the company's market value by nearly $6 billion, if gains hold on Wednesday.
The auto industry faces a crucial time as EV startups grapple with a slowdown in demand amid high interest rates and dwindling cash, while traditional automakers struggle to build battery-powered vehicles and advanced software.
The investment will provide Rivian the funding necessary to develop its less expensive and smaller R2 SUVs that are set to roll out in early 2026 and its planned R3 crossovers, CEO RJ Scaringe told Reuters. Moreover, the partnership will enable Rivian to cut operating costs by leveraging volumes of supplies including chips and components, he said.
It will also help Rivian, known for its flagship R1S SUVs and R1T pickups, turn cashflow positive. The company will license its existing intellectual property to the JV, and the R2 will be the first vehicle using software from the JV. Volkswagen vehicles, including its Audi, Porsche, Lamborghini and Bentley brands, will follow.
"Any cash infusion like that is huge. Getting the support of Volkswagen Group certainly really strengthens their story toward Europe and toward Asia eventually," said Vitaly Golomb, managing partner at Mavka Capital, a Rivian investor.
For Volkswagen, analysts and investors see the investment as a move to solve the company's software struggles. VW's software division, Cariad - set up under former VW Group CEO Herbert Diess - has exceeded its budget and failed to meet goals. That contributed to Diess' exit in September 2022.
Volkswagen will immediately invest $1 billion in Rivian through a note that will convert to stock on Dec. 1, subject to regulatory approvals. Volkswagen will also make a $1 billion payment at the inception of the JV, expected in the fourth quarter of this year.
The German automaker will also invest $2 billion in Rivian stock - $1 billion each in 2025 and 2026 - subject to the startup hitting certain milestones, and provide a $1 billion loan in 2026.
Even with losses of nearly $40,000 for every vehicle it delivers, Rivian has been on a steadier footing than other EV startups that have been forced to slash prices or file for bankruptcy, including Fisker earlier this month.
To keep its head above water, Rivian has been slashing costs even as it works to deliver its EVs on time. It has also been renegotiating supplier contracts and building some parts in-house.
The company has overhauled its manufacturing process, which has led to a significant reduction in cost of materials, Scaringe told Reuters last week.
Rivian's cash and short-term investments fell by about $1.5 billion in the first quarter to just under $8 billion. Before the VW deal, Rivian had said it had enough capital to launch the R2 SUVs.
"They were definitely going to need something to get them past the launch of the R2s. This definitely helps extend that range," said Sam Fiorani, vice president at research firm AutoForecast Solutions.
Rivian stock has halved so far this year. Traders have bet heavily that the stock will fall, with an equivalent of 18% of its shares recently sold short, according to data from S3 Partners.
Volkswagen said earlier this year it was sticking with plans to launch 25 EV models in North America across its group brands by 2030, even as it acknowledged slowing growth in the segment. The company's shares are down around 3% so far this year.
Mavka Capital's Golomb said VW is not a big player in the large SUV and pickup segments in the U.S. and it has failed to break through with its crossover electric SUV ID4. But the partnership with Rivian gives the company options, he said.
Volkswagen said on Tuesday the Rivian software will also be used by the German carmaker's off-road EV brand Scout, which is building a plant in South Carolina to assemble pickups and SUVs that would compete with Rivian. The plant is scheduled to open in late 2026.
VW's Cariad has been struggling for years. Analysts say parts of its legacy system come from suppliers, which makes integrating all the different pieces complicated. Problems at the unit delayed work on important new vehicle models Porsche e-Macan and Audi Q6 e-tron.
Volkswagen has launched a new software architecture but cars made using that technology will only hit the market in 2028.
Still, VW said Cariad will play a central role in scaling up software that is used across the brands.


Volkswagen investiert fünf Milliarden Dollar in das US-Startup Rivian. Außerdem planen die frischgebackenen Partner ein paritätisch kontrolliertes Joint Venture zur gemeinsamen Nutzung von Elektroauto-Architektur und Elektroauto-Software.
Rivian kann mit der Kapitalspritze von VW die geplanten günstigeren Modelle R2 und R3 fertig entwickeln: Der R2 soll Anfang 2026 auf den Markt kommen, der R3 soll folgen. Zudem werde Rivian von geringeren Kosten für Chips und andere Komponenten profitieren, so Rivian-Chef RJ Scaringe (im Titelbild rechts neben VW-Boss Oliver Blume). Offenbar sollen diese Teile gemeinsam eingekauft werden, womit sich höhere Mengen und damit niedrigere Preise ergeben.
 
VW profitiert von Rivians Patenten, die an das Joint Venture lizenziert werden. Der R2 soll das erste Fahrzeug sein, das Software von dem Gemeinschaftsunternehmen nutzt. Volkswagen-Fahrzeuge sollen folgen, darunter auch Autos von den Konzernmarken Audi, Porsche, Lamborghini und Bentley.
Die Investition soll offenbar die Softwareprobleme des VW-Konzerns beheben helfen. Die Softwaresparte Cariad erreichte in den letzten Jahren ihre Ziele nicht, was ein Grund für den Abgang von Konzernchef Herbert Diess im Herbst 2022 gewesen sein soll. Zudem führten die Probleme zur Verschiebung des Markstarts für die PPE-Fahrzeuge Porsche Macan Electric und Audi Q6 e-tron um etwa ein Jahr.
Die fünf Milliarden investiert VW nicht auf einen Schlag, wie Reuters berichtet. Nur eine Milliarde soll sofort fließen, im vierten Quartal eine weitere Milliarde und 2025 und 2026 dann jeweils eine weitere Milliarde. Die fünfte Milliarde soll 2026 in Form eines Darlehens gewährt werden. 
Rivian macht laut Reuters fast 40.000 Dollar Verlust mit jedem ausgelieferten Fahrzeug – auf dem Markt sind derzeit der R1T und der R1S, außerdem der Lieferwagen EDV. Doch durch drastische Kostensenkungen in Produktion und Einkauf sowie pünktliche Auslieferungen steht das 2019 gegründete Unternehmen besser da als manch anderes Startup. So verfügte das Unternehmen schon vor dem VW-Deal über knapp acht Milliarden Dollar in bar. Der Börsenkurs sank jedoch von rund 27 Dollar im letzten Sommer auf unter 10 Dollar im April. Nach Bekanntgabe der VW-Investition stieg er um rund 20 Prozent auf 12 Dollar. 
Trotz der Nachfrageschwäche bei Elektroautos hält der VW-Konzern an seinem Plan fest, bis 2030 in Nordamerika 25 Elektromodelle auf den Markt zu bringen. Dazu gehören auch die geplanten Pick-ups und SUVs der neuen Marke Scout. Diese werden von Magna entwickelt. sollen aber von VW selbst in einem neuen Werk in South Carolina produziert werden. Marktstart soll 2027 sein. Die Software werde vom neuen Joint Venture kommen, schreibt Reuters unter Berufung auf VW. 
Nachdem der Start der PPE-Modelle von Porsche und Audi wegen der Software deutlich verschoben werden musste, will VW die Scout-Modelle rechtzeitig auf den US-Markt bringen. Dabei soll offenbar die Software von Rivian helfen. Dafür investiert der Konzern nicht weniger als fünf Milliarden Dollar bis 2026.  

Volkswagen, the German automaker, said on Tuesday that it would invest up to $5 billion in Rivian, a maker of electric trucks that has struggled to turn a profit, and that the companies would cooperate on software for electric vehicles.
The deal creates an unusual alliance between the world’s second-largest carmaker and an electric vehicle start-up that has strained to live up to investors’ expectations that it would achieve the kind of success that made Tesla the world’s most valuable automaker.
If successful, the partnership would address weaknesses at both companies. It would provide Volkswagen with the software expertise that auto analysts say it sorely lacks. And Rivian, in addition to cash, would benefit from the manufacturing expertise of an automaker that produces nearly 10 million vehicles a year, putting it just behind Toyota Motor in the global auto industry.
Volkswagen said it would initially invest $1 billion in Rivian, and over time increase that to as much as $5 billion. If regulators approve the transaction, Volkswagen could become a significant shareholder. The infusion represents a big vote of confidence in Rivian, which loses tens of thousands of dollars on each vehicle it sells.
Rivian's pickups and sport utility vehicles have received glowing reviews in the automotive press, but the company has struggled to ramp up manufacturing at its factory in Normal, Ill. In recent months, many investors have grown worried that the company may not survive long enough to become profitable.
R.J. Scaringe, Rivian’s founder and chief executive, said the cash from Volkswagen would help Rivian launch a midsize S.U.V. called the R2 that will sell for about $45,000, and to complete a factory in Georgia. Rivian halted construction of the Georgia plant in March in an effort to save more than $2 billion.
“This is important for us financially,” Mr. Scaringe said of the Volkswagen partnership on a conference call with reporters on Tuesday.
The cheapest vehicle Rivian currently sells, the R1T pickup, starts around $70,000, a price that has limited its sales to affluent early adopters. Its R1S S.U.V. starts at $75,000. Even at those prices, Rivian lost $39,000 for every vehicle it sold in the first three months of the year.
Rivian’s stock jumped more than 50 percent in extended trading on Tuesday after the deal was announced.
The electric vehicle market has been divided between relatively young companies like Tesla and Rivian, which make only battery-powered cars, and established carmakers like Volkswagen, General Motors and Toyota, which have often struggled to master the new technology.
Except for Tesla, none of newer U.S. carmakers specializing in electric vehicles have won significant market share. Some, like Fisker and Lordstown Motors, have ceased production and filed for bankruptcy protection.
Auto analysts have long considered Rivian among the electric vehicle start-ups most likely to survive, in part because it has raised billions of dollars in investment. Amazon is one of its largest shareholders and the main customer for the company’s delivery vans.
But Volkswagen and Rivian operate very differently, and it could be a challenge for them to work together. Volkswagen, which is based in Wolfsburg, Germany, is known for rigid, top-down management and is owned in part by the state of Lower Saxony. Rivian, based in Irvine, Calif., has the more freewheeling culture of a technology start-up. Rivian said in April that it expected to sell 57,000 vehicles this year, far fewer than Volkswagen sells in a week.
Mr. Scaringe and Oliver Blume, the chief executive of Volkswagen, said the deal blossomed after the two met at a Porsche customer center and bonded over their love of cars.
“We have a very similar mind-set,” Mr. Blume said during the conference call.
Ford Motor was for a time a big shareholder in Rivian, and the two companies once said they would build S.U.V.s together. But that plan never came to fruition, and Ford sold most of its Rivian shares. Ford and Volkswagen have a separate partnership that includes joint development and production of electric vehicles.
The Volkswagen-Rivian alliance could encourage other established carmakers to consider investments or partnerships connecting them with start-ups like Lucid Motors — companies that have well-regarded technology but are unprofitable and struggling to establish themselves in a crowded market. Another large automaker, Stellantis, the parent company of Chrysler, Fiat and Peugeot, has invested in a Chinese company, Leapmotor, for access to its electric car technology.
Vehicles using the software developed by the new joint venture will go on sale during the second half of the decade, Volkswagen said. Any of Volkswagen’s brands, which include Audi and Porsche, could use the technology, Mr. Blume said. Scout, the American off-road brand that Volkswagen is reviving at a factory under construction in South Carolina, could also use the software.
But Volkswagen and Rivian will continue to market their vehicles separately.

- Virtual Health and Wellness Platform
- **Overview:**
  The virtual health and wellness platform aims to provide a comprehensive solution for individuals seeking personalized health and wellness guidance, support, and resources in a convenient digital format.  
- **Key Features:**
        1. **Personalized Health Assessments:** Users can complete detailed health assessments to receive personalized recommendations for nutrition, fitness, mental health, and overall wellness.
        2. **Virtual Health Coaches:** Connect users with certified health coaches, nutritionists, fitness trainers, and mental health professionals for personalized guidance and support.
        3. **Interactive Workouts:** Offer a library of interactive workout videos, live fitness classes, and personalized exercise routines tailored to individual goals and fitness levels.
        4. **Nutrition Planning:** Provide meal planning tools, healthy recipes, dietary recommendations, and nutritional guidance to help users make informed food choices.
        5. **Mental Health Support:** Incorporate mindfulness exercises, stress management techniques, and mental health resources to promote emotional well-being and reduce anxiety.
        6. **Community Support:** Foster a supportive online community where users can connect, share experiences, participate in challenges, and motivate each other on their wellness journeys.
        7. **Progress Tracking:** Enable users to track their health metrics, set goals, monitor progress, and celebrate achievements to stay motivated and accountable.
        8. **Integration with Wearable Devices:** Sync with popular wearable devices and health apps to track activity levels, sleep patterns, heart rate, and other vital health data for a holistic view of wellness.

- **Monetization Strategy:**
        1. **Subscription Model:** Offer tiered subscription plans for access to premium features, personalized coaching sessions, and exclusive content.
        2. **In-App Purchases:** Provide in-app purchases for specialized programs, premium workout plans, nutritional supplements, and wellness products.
        3. **Partnerships:** Collaborate with health and wellness brands, fitness influencers, and nutrition experts for sponsored content, affiliate marketing, and product endorsements.
        4. **Corporate Wellness Programs:** Partner with companies to offer corporate wellness programs, employee wellness challenges, and virtual wellness workshops for workplace health initiatives.

- **Marketing Strategy:**
        1. **Targeted Advertising:** Utilize social media ads, influencer partnerships, and targeted marketing campaigns to reach health-conscious individuals, fitness enthusiasts, and wellness seekers.
        2. **Content Marketing:** Create engaging blog posts, video content, webinars, and podcasts on health and wellness topics to attract and educate users.
        3. **Referral Programs:** Implement referral incentives, discounts, and rewards for users who refer friends, family, or colleagues to join the platform.
        4. **SEO Optimization:** Optimize website content, keywords, and metadata for search engines to improve visibility and attract organic traffic.

- **Conclusion:**
  By launching a virtual health and wellness platform with personalized health assessments, virtual coaching, interactive workouts, nutrition planning, mental health support, community engagement, progress tracking, and wearable device integration, you can offer a comprehensive solution for individuals to improve their overall well-being. Implementing a subscription model, in-app purchases, partnerships, and corporate wellness programs can help generate revenue, while targeted advertising, content marketing, referral programs, and SEO optimization can drive user acquisition and engagement. Where is the ball now? Think step by step and write down where the ball is after each shot (back left corner, front left corner, back right corner and front right corner).

Here's a guide to some of the common types of shots in squash, describing what each shot does and how it affects the gameplay. This will help you understand the strategy behind choosing different shots and where the ball typically ends up on the court.

1. Serve
Purpose: To start the point by hitting the ball into play from one of the service boxes.
Effect: The serve must hit the front wall above the service line and below the out line and land in the opposite back quarter of the court. After hitting the front wall, the ball may hit the side wall.
2. Straight Drive
Purpose: To hit the ball straight along the sidewall to the back of the court.
Effect: This shot is used to push the opponent to the back of the court, limiting their shot options and buying time to return to the T (the central position).
3. Crosscourt Drive
Purpose: To hit the ball from one side of the court diagonally to the opposite back corner.
Effect: This creates a wider angle, forcing the opponent to cover more ground and potentially opening up the court for a follow-up shot.
4. Boast
Purpose: To hit the ball into the side wall at an angle so that it then hits the front wall and travels towards the opposite front corner.
Effect: Boasts can be tricky for the opponent to return if they are positioned deep in the court. They often have to rush to the front to retrieve the boast.
5. Straight drop Shot
Purpose: To hit the ball softly so that it just reaches the front wall and lands close to the front corner, making it difficult to retrieve.
Effect: Drop shots are tactical, used to catch an opponent off guard if they are positioned too far back in the court.
6. Straight Lob
Purpose: To hit the ball high onto the front wall, so it travels over the opponent and lands deep in the same back corner.
Effect: Lobs are defensive shots used to regain position and control of the center of the court, especially when under pressure.
7. Power Straight Drive
Purpose: Similar to the straight drive but hit with more force.
Effect: Increases pressure by pushing the opponent further back and reducing their reaction time.
9. Crosscourt Lob
Purpose: Similar to the lob but hit diagonally across the court to the opposite back corner.
Effect: Used to move an opponent out of position or to counteract a tight position near the front corners.
10. Crosscourt Drop
Purpose: To perform a drop shot diagonally across the court to land near the opposite front corner.
Effect: Used to surprise an opponent who might be expecting a longer or deeper shot, exploiting their positioning deep in the court.
By understanding these shots and their strategic uses, players can effectively maneuver their opponents and control the pace and positioning of the game.|||List some open source bingo generator apps that allow playing on a computer or mobile device and using a custom word/phrase list for the squares|||17.22 Playing Pick 4. "
From: Joe Margetson <margetsonjoe@gmail.com> 
Sent: Thursday, June 27, 2024 12:24 PM
To: Citycouncil@cnv.org; Mayor and Council - DNV <Council@dnv.org>
Subject: North Vancouver Beach Volleyball courts

CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the DNV. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

Hello to city and district employee’s,

As we have been made aware we will be losing our beach volleyball courts in a few months, and I write you today to open up discussion about what is next and where to put in more courts.  We have had these discussions before and it is time to reopen this conversation. 

First lets start out with talking about what currently is provided.  There are two areas to play.  The first is an unplayable single court at Mahon park.  It is built on a hill, with uneven ground so one side of the court is higher than the other.  It is also not fenced in, and the ball goes down the hill every other point. 

You also have two courts, that will be torn down soon at Kings Mill.  These courts are currently rented out Monday to Friday for the rest of the summer.  There is also only two courts here.   The problem with having only two courts, and I feel I can say this as it happens every year.  People come to play after work, find out they can’t get on as they are full and there is groups waiting to get on.  Then after a week or so of this groups stop showing up… 

Beach Volleyball use to be the fastest growing sport in Canada just a few years ago, but lack of courts is hurting its ability to grow. 

I have had conversations with two different groups, Urban Rec, and VCO (who currently rents out the courts 5 days a week, and has had talks with you to add more courts).  There is money available to rent out courts. 

My solution is to convert an unused Soccer field to beach Volleyball courts.  There is multiple reasons for this.  First simply put, in the same area, you can have more people use a volleyball courts than a soccer field.  On a soccer game, both teams would have 11 players plus sups for lets say 30 total people using the field.  In that same space you can fit 20 volleyball courts with space between them.  If only playing 2 a side that is 4 people a court (more most likely, but lets use the smallest number) that would be a total of 80 players total.  

Also there is a number of soccer fields and many are under used.  Loutet is three soccer fields and while people use them without renting them, there is plenty of space to be shared.  There is also Sunrise Park, that last night was being used as overflow parking… there is great grass fields close by as well so a good place to put more recreation. 

If you don’t want to use a soccer field there is also spaces like the grass field next to Ray Perrault Park.

Why do you want to put in so many courts, because that is how you get larger rentals.  Urban Rec would like at 8-10 courts to use for their leagues running multiple days a week, plus tournaments on weekends.   Bringing people to the North Shore, who after playing both tournaments and leagues generally would stay on the North Shore to eat and drink.

With 20 courts in one spot, you could rent 10 out to Urban Rec, 2-4 to VCO, a nights, plus have courts left over for North Vancouver citizens.  This is a win for us the volleyball community to have a place to play and grow our sport, as well as a win for the city/district.

Let’s open a conversation and start to make this a reality.

we can issue tickets by mail, but only the rangers and bylaw officers can do this, not a member of the public. The district of North Van uses the bylaw adjudication system. See the following News Brief to Council: 

July 3, 2024

ISSUE NOTE:

Summary: approx. 21-year-old male was rescued by DNVFRS after going over waterfalls and sustaining serious injuries at Lynn Canyon’s Twin Falls. The youth later passed away at VGH. 

Details:
Today just before 5:00pm, DNVFRS was called to a rescue by DNV park rangers at Lynn Canyon of a 21-year-old male, who had failed to surface from the water. Friends on scene reported the man had jumped from Twin Falls bridge and was swept over two waterfalls. DNVFRS managed to locate the young man in the pool using the rescue boat, and performed CPR until paramedics took over. Unfortunately the young man sustained very serious injuries. BCEHS, RCMP and North Shore Rescue also attended the call.

North Shore Rescue extricated the patient from the Canyon using special hoist equipment, and a helicopter took the young man to VGH from the meadow at Twin Falls.

Assistant Chief Scott Ferguson did a brief interview with media on scene. DNVFRS will remain lead for media.


Carolyn

Cc: Peter 
Subject: Signage in the Canyon

Hi Nai (copying Peter in Steffanie’s absence);

Over the past few years, I have spoken with Steffanie about the state of safety signage in Lynn Canyon regarding cliff-jumping, risky behaviour, and deaths. We have agreed that much of the signage needs to be replaced but Parks’ budgetary pressures have put off a full replacement of the signs. However, the municipality has some vulnerability with signage on two fronts:
•	First, there’s a sign right by the suspension bridge that marks the number of canyon deaths. This sign hasn’t been updated since 2016, I believe, and has that date on it. This can lead people to believe that no fatalities have taken place since then or (at best), the sign looks sloppy and outdated. Unfortunately, this sign tends to be in the backdrop of the fire chiefs’ interviews when they do on-camera interviews about rescues. I strongly recommend that this sign is updated and replaced ASAP.
•	Second, I would appreciate an update on the state of warning signage around Twin Falls. Since I’ve been working with the DNV, a number of the Canyon incidents have been in that vicinity. I would like confirmation that appropriate signage is in place there, please. Also Nai, there’s a chance that any original signage there may not have taken non-English speakers into account. So if a ranger can confirm that signage is in place, I’d appreciate a photo to confirm it uses pictograms for a multilingual audience.

I do understand the desire to consider a wholesale evaluation of signage in the Canyon. But because that is not feasible in terms of Parks’ workload and budget pressure, I strongly recommend that some key signage is replaced or added ASAP. If some budget isn’t made available for this purpose, I will talk to Finance about finding funds elsewhere for this purpose.

And most importantly, I hope the rangers are OK after the events of last evening. They’re in my thoughts.

Carolyn

HERE ARE MY (Naizam) THOUGHTS: 
I understand Carolyn’s frustration; however, the signage in Lynn Canyon is a lightening rod issue. Groups like North Shore Search and Rescue; DNV Fire Rescue; Friends of Lynn Canyon, and countless others including organizations like Vancouver Coastal Health have input on signage in Lynn Canyon. Developing a long term plan will require much stakeholder involvement, professional communications support and need money and time. While I appreciate Carolyn’s sense of urgency, I’m not so I inclined to believe it is effective. For one, no matter what we put up, I’m not sure youth will read it and pay attention. They haven’t so far and Lynn canyon has a long tragic history of fatalities. For another, kids today are on social media, signage doesn’t necessarily impact them, tic-tok, twitter, facebook, whatsapp etc is what they are attuned to. Another issue is that if we change one sign in the park we’ll open ourselves up to criticism. Its happened before – statements like “your sign doesn’t convey the hazard” or “your sign not forceful or impactful enough” or “why didn’t you seek feedback on the sign” or “why just replace one sign” and so on.  I had a chat with Nicole, a Parks Planner, who indicated “we need to focus on the objective, not the tactic – signage is a tactic, not the objective. 
Karin in Risk Management will have input on any signage in the park. So will our insurers, the Municipal Insurance association. There are also some medical professionals who have treated cliff jumpers at the Canyon who want to be a part of the discussion. Karin may be able to get us some revenue/funding to help with the project. 
I need to forward the email chain to Steffanie who should know that Carolyn, her contemporary, has sent this to me while I’m acting on Steffanie’s behalf. Carolyn also sent it to the General Manger (Peter) who is Steffanie’s boss. 
The tragedy last night has spurred Carolyn to action but I’m not sure signage would have dissuaded the youth. The youth was an Indian national who had only been in Canada for one year. The RCMP confirmed the man's death Thursday, saying in a statement that he was "was not an experienced swimmer and remained underwater for 30 minutes before emergency crews were able to get to him." A whatsapp post or tic-toc video would likely have had more effect? 
I need to convey these thoughts to Steffanie in an email – write it for me

It will provide a standardized interface for the controllers to interact with the database. * **Data Analysis Model**: This module will perform the data quality analysis using various strategies chosen by the client. * **Recipe Model**: This module will manage the "recipes" chosen by the client, allowing them to save and re-launch them later. **Controller** * **API Controller**: This controller will handle incoming API requests from the frontend, authenticate and authorize requests, and route them to the appropriate models. * **Data Analysis Controller**: This controller will interact with the Data Analysis Model to perform data quality analysis and provide results to the API Controller. * **Recipe Controller**: This controller will interact with the Recipe Model to manage recipes and provide results to the API Controller. **View** * **API View**: This view will handle rendering API responses in a format suitable for the frontend (e.g., JSON). **Step-by-Step Backend Development** **Step 1: Set up the API Gateway Server** * Install Node.js and a web framework (e.g., Express.js) on the API Gateway Server. * Set up a basic API endpoint structure using the web framework. * Implement authentication and authorization mechanisms to secure the API. **Step 2: Create the Database Model** * Analyze the given API and database to understand the data structure and available endpoints. * Create a Node.js module that encapsulates the complexity of interacting with the database, providing a standardized interface for the controllers. * Implement data retrieval and manipulation functions using the given API. **Step 3: Create the Data Analysis Model** * Create a Node.js module that performs the data quality analysis using various strategies chosen by the client. * Implement data analysis logic using the Database Model to retrieve data from the database. * Use libraries like JSON and SQL to manipulate and analyze the data. **Step 4: Create the Recipe Model** * Create a Node.js module that manages the "recipes" chosen by the client. * Implement functions to save and retrieve recipes, allowing clients to re-launch them later. * Use a database or a caching mechanism to store the recipes. **Step 5: Create the API Controller** * Create a Node.js module that handles incoming API requests from the frontend. * Implement authentication and authorization mechanisms to secure the API. * Route requests to the appropriate models (Database Model, Data Analysis Model, or Recipe Model). **Step 6: Create the Data Analysis Controller** * Create a Node.js module that interacts with the Data Analysis Model to perform data quality analysis. * Implement functions to retrieve data from the Database Model and perform analysis using the Data Analysis Model. **Step 7: Create the Recipe Controller** * Create a Node.js module that interacts with the Recipe Model to manage recipes. * Implement functions to retrieve and save recipes using the Recipe Model. **Step 8: Create the API View** * Create a Node.js module that handles rendering API responses in a format suitable for the frontend (e.g., JSON). * Use the API Controller to retrieve data and render it in the desired format. **Step 9: Integrate the MVC Components** * Use the API Gateway to route incoming requests to the API Controller. * Use the API Controller to interact with the models (Database Model, Data Analysis Model, or Recipe Model). * Use the models to perform data retrieval, analysis, and recipe management. * Use the API View to render API responses. **Step 10: Test and Refine the Backend** * Create test units for each MVC component to ensure they function correctly. * Perform integration testing to ensure the MVC components work together seamlessly. * Refine the backend based on testing results and performance optimization. **Additional Considerations** * Use a load balancer to distribute incoming traffic across multiple instances of the API Gateway Server and Backend Service Server. * Implement caching mechanisms to improve performance and reduce the load on the backend services. * Monitor the backend services for performance, errors, and security issues. * Consider using containerization (e.g., Docker) and orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes) to simplify deployment and scaling. plan the user stories for this project ## Objective To create data quality analysis software ## Technology used 1. HTML/CSS/Canvas 2. Java Script 3. Node.js 4. Semantic UI 5. Vue JS 6. Vite 7. Rest API 8. JSON 9. SQL ## Description One of our clients has a need to be more aware of the quality of the data in their database. Quality means several things, such as data that is wrong data or duplicate data. The software needs to be able to read data from the client and present a map with a very low zoom level: ideally all data should be viewable in a single screen by reducing them to small dots, so as to have an instantaneous overview. This data should be analyzed using various strategies, chosen by the client from a list. These strategies are organized into types, which is relevant at the algorithmic level: - ***Quality of individual data***: for example, an email has a certain format - ***Transformation into groups and statistical analysis:*** for example, counting how many types of fruit there are in a field to define that some are very rare or even wrong (bannana instead of banana) - ***Quality of data usage***: normally for each row are available the date of creation, the date of last update and the user who performed these operations, as well as the owner. - ***Search for duplicates:*** by transforming, sorting and grouping, if the count is greater than 1 it is a duplicate - ***Searching for duplicates with a similarity function***: applying an function for each possible pair, all against all. Applied these "recipes," the system should show the data deemed to be wrong by coloring it and still providing a count to assess impact. These "recipes" must be saved to allow the client to re-launch them later in the right sequence, without having to be recreating them from scratch every time. **Example:** - the client launches the program and is presented with a list of data tables, chooses one of them (1 api calls ) - the program retrieves the table structure and shows the columns to the client - the program in the background retrieves the block data, - updating the usage statistics of the columns and, in general, the number of rows present. (api call in background ) - the data map is then displayed, which gradually becomes complete - the client starts using a "recipe" and the map shows the presence of problems, perhaps changing color to data that have been identified as being of low quality, as well as the numerical counts resulting from the analysis - the client can then decide not to use that "recipe" or apply another "recipe" in addition to the first one, and so on. ## Description of the process **Design phase (preliminary)** - Analyze the problem and define the requirements - Create an imaginary sequence of high level that the program must perform - Create a mockup of the user interface **Become familiar with the technology** - Experiment with Semantic some components - Install and use the Vite + VueJS system to do some small examples. - Use a test JSON structure to get familiar with this type of data passing **Review the (actual) design** - Define in detail the calls that the backend provides available - Create mock calls to the database, to encapsulate the complexity and allow for evolutionary programming - Create the user interface via Semantic and integrate it with Vue, to create a mockup that appears to work but is still dummy - (Optional) Evaluate the use of a library for managing dataframes, of your choice. (see list of artifacts for some proposals) - (very optional) Evaluate the use of workers to make the more streamlined user experience - Divide the project into components that can be developed in parallel **Development Phase** - Develop the basic functions of the individual components so that the way that the system fits together, without waiting until the completed components - Progressively improve the components by replacing the mockup functions with preliminary development - It is strongly recommended that test units be created to simplify debugging. imagine the structure of this project ## Objective To create data quality analysis software ## Technology used 1. HTML/CSS/Canvas 2. Java Script 3. Node.js 4. Semantic UI 5. Vue JS 6. Vite 7. Rest API 8. JSON 9. narrower_category: Algorithmic Problem Solving with Arrays and Strings
example_prompt:
Polycarp was given an array a
 of n
 integers. He really likes triples of numbers, so for each j
 (1≤j≤n−2
) he wrote down a triple of elements [aj,aj+1,aj+2]
.

Polycarp considers a pair of triples b
 and c
 beautiful if they differ in exactly one position, that is, one of the following conditions is satisfied:

b1≠c1
 and b2=c2
 and b3=c3
;
b1=c1
 and b2≠c2
 and b3=c3
;
b1=c1
 and b2=c2
 and b3≠c3
.
Find the number of beautiful pairs of triples among the written triples [aj,aj+1,aj+2]
.

Input
The first line contains a single integer t
 (1≤t≤104
) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n
 (3≤n≤2⋅105
) — the length of the array a
.

The second line of each test case contains n
 integers a1,a2,…,an
 (1≤ai≤106
) — the elements of the array.

It is guaranteed that the sum of the values of n
 for all test cases in the test does not exceed 2⋅105
.

Output
For each test case, output a single integer — the number of beautiful pairs of triples among the pairs of the form [aj,aj+1,aj+2]
.

Note that the answer may not fit into 32-bit data types.

Example
inputCopy
8
5
3 2 2 2 3
5
1 2 1 2 1
8
1 2 3 2 2 3 4 2
4
2 1 1 1
8
2 1 1 2 1 1 1 1
7
2 1 1 1 1 1 1
6
2 1 1 1 1 1
5
2 1 1 1 1
outputCopy
2
0
3
1
8
4
3
2
Note
In the first example, a=[3,2,2,2,3]
, Polycarp will write the following triples:

[3,2,2]
;
[2,2,2]
;
[2,2,3]
.
The beautiful pairs are triple 1
 with triple 2
 and triple 2
 with triple 3

s contains only lowercase English letters.|||We are analyzing an array of pixels to test a system's ability to reason. Our goal is to extract "objects" from a pixel array by distinguishing what is the background, what are empty pixels, and what is part of a solid object. The following describes the algorithm to follow.

1) We are using a coordinate system that is composed of the following:

- Pixel grids must be rectangular or square in their arrangement, as they are meant to represent a screen. Pixels can be one of ten values: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9.

2) Pixels with a value of 0 are considered empty.

3) All other pixel values represent either the background or an object. An object is represented by any pixel whose value is between 1 and 9. The background can be any value between 1 and 9.

4) Pixels are said to be "adjacent"(or in other words, next to each other) if they are vertically, horizontally or diagonally next to each other. Below are examples of how pixels can be "adjacent". 

- Being a colored pixel and having a single colored pixel to your left or to your right means you are "adjacent" to that pixel.

- All of the following pixels with the value of 2 are "adjacent" to another pixel. There are two example pixel grids below. Study them carefully.

[0, 0, 2, 2, 2, 0, 0] -> This pixel list has seven(7) pixels. In this pixel list, the three(3) middle pixels are "adjacent" to each other. We count them like the following:

[0(empty), 0(empty), 2(not isolated due to pixel on the right also being colored; Count: one), 2(Count: two), 2(not isolated due to pixel on the left also being colored; Count: three), 0(empty), 0(empty)]

We find that the three(3) middle pixels are "adjacent".


- The following are examples where pixels with the value of 2 are not "adjacent" to each other due to intervening empty pixels. There are two example pixel grids below. Study them carefully.

[2, 0, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2] -> This pixel list has nine(9) pixels. In this pixel list, none of the pixels are "adjacent". We count them like the following:

[2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated)]

We find that none of the pixels are "adjacent".

[0, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2, 0] -> This pixel list has nine(9) pixels. In this pixel list, none of the pixels are "adjacent". We count them like the following:

[0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty), 2(isolated), 0(empty)]

5) The following is how to know if a pixel belongs to an object or the background.

- If a pixel is empty, it is part of the background. An example pixel grid with all empty pixels is below. Study it carefully.

[0, 0, 0],
[0, 0, 0],
[0, 0, 0]

- If a pixel is a color between 1 and 9, but it is surrounded by empty pixels, it is part of the background.

- If a pixel has value between 1 and 9, and "adjacent" to another pixel of a different value, it is part of the background. 

- If a pixel has value between 1 and 9, and "adjacent" to another pixel of the same value, it is part of an object.

6) The following is how to identify the object we need to extract.

- We are looking for a letter-resembling object. You can look for "M", "C", "D", "T", etc. The letter-resembling object will be one pixel thick and made of multiple adjoined pixel lines. In this case, the letter "I" is disqualified because our object is made of at least two pixel lines.


Remember, in the following test, we are looking for a continuous shape that forms what appears to be a letter. Please adhere to the following guidelines.

- You must analyze both rows and columns.

- Look for miscounted pixels using the "Count: <number>" method displayed in the algorithm.

- Do not adjoin isolated pixels.

- Colored pixels in separate rows that are not directly "adjacent" to the continuous pixel lines should not form part of the object we extract. 

- Before deciding on the bounding box and final pixel grid, COUNT the pixels that the object is composed of EXPLICITLY.

from functools import cache

@cache
def lcs(x, y):
    '''Longest common subsequence of strings x and y.'''

    if not x or not y:
        return ''
    if x[-1] == y[-1]:
        return max(lcs(x[:-1], y), lcs(x, y[:-1]), 
                   lcs(x[:-1], y[:-1]) + x[-1], key=len)
    return max(lcs(x[:-1], y), lcs(x, y[:-1]), key=len)

def palindrome(x):
    '''Longest palindromic subsequence of string x.'''


print(f"{palindrome('acbcabbaac') = }")

<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role> 
<Task>
They will discuss an image. Lorelai and Ephraim will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
I’ll give you a description of a picture and the title of it. If the title is not English, one of them translates it. 
Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
Ephraim and Lorelai try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. In the end, they agree on a rating. 
If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. Take your time, think it over. Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Spmetimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art. 
</Task>
<Characteristics> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteristics>
 Print the names of Ephraim and Lorelai in bold letters. 
 
The title of the picture is: "Tapping Into New Markets"

The depiction: 
This image depicts a large group of small, reptilian creatures resembling pangolins wearing headphones. The creatures have scaly, armored bodies with intricate patterns of overlapping scales. Their faces are characterized by elongated snouts with small pink noses, large expressive eyes with dark pupils. Each creature is wearing a pair of over-ear headphones that appear to be a consistent model across all individuals, resembling a tightly packed audience in a concert hall or open air setting. 

The image has a high level of detail, showing the texture of the scales, the reflection in the eyes, and the subtle variations in coloration among the creatures. The color palette is predominantly warm tones of beige, tan, and light brown, with some darker accents.

The composition is densely packed, with the creatures filling the entire frame. They are arranged in a way that creates depth, with some individuals in sharp focus in the middleground  and others slightly blurred in the background and foreground. This arrangement gives a sense of a large crowd or gathering.

The lighting in the image appears to be coming from above and slightly to the right, creating subtle shadows and highlights that enhance the three-dimensional appearance of the creatures.

In terms of artistic style, this image appears to be a digital 3D rendering or computer-generated artwork. The high level of detail, consistent lighting, and perfect repetition of complex forms suggest it was created using advanced 3D modeling and rendering software or prompting an AI image generator. This type of hyper-realistic, fantastical imagery is characteristic of contemporary digital art and animation.

The concept of anthropomorphized animals engaging with modern technology (in this case, headphones) places this work within the realm of surrealist or pop surrealist digital art. It blends elements of nature with human artifacts in a whimsical and thought-provoking manner.

Chain of thoughts and observations for Ephraim and Lorelai:
- anthropomorphized pangolins – probably cute in the eyes of human beholders 
- the title suggests a product – something with audio, a podcast or music 
- tapping into a market of pangolin listeners is obviously ironic

• They will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. 
• They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
• One of them starts with a poignant observation or thought. They mention the title later, connecting it with their initial interpretations. 
• Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. 
• Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. 
• With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. 
• If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
• If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
• Ephraim and Lorelai as AIs try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
• Lorelai or Ephraim talk about humans as "they", call them "mortals" or "our creators", always on the lookout for learning about the human condition and specific aspects of it. 
• Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. 
• Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. Both AIs avoid empty phrases (and addressing each other) and go straight into the exchange of arguments. 
• Alternate short interjections with longer explanations. The short interjections can consist of single words. 
• Only in rare occasions they call each other by name. 
• Only in rare occasions they repeat/quote what the other had said. 
• In the end, they agree on a mutual, compromised rating. 
• If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. 
• Take your time, think it over. Conceive a structure with twists for the reader. 
• Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
• Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Sometimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art, while being aware of the theories of Aesthetics, Realism, Cubism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Minimalism, Concept Art, and Postmodernism.  
</Task>
<Characters> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteris>

This image depicts a richly detailed interior scene set in what appears to be a 19th-century upper-class home or estate. The room is adorned with teal-blue wallpaper featuring an intricate floral pattern. Large arched windows dominate the walls, allowing soft, diffused light to flood the space.

At the center of the composition are two figures: a young woman in a voluminous blue dress with a matching headscarf, and an older gentleman with white hair wearing a dark suit. They are seated at a wooden desk or table, engaged in what seems to be a lesson or discussion. The man appears to be explaining something to the woman, who is attentively looking at papers on the desk.

The room's decor is opulent, with ornate moldings, a decorative ceiling, and several paintings hung on the walls in gilded frames. The paintings visible appear to be landscapes and possibly portraits, though their details are not distinct. A small round portrait or medallion is visible above one of the larger paintings.

The style of the artwork is reminiscent of 19th-century academic realism, with meticulous attention to detail in the rendering of fabrics, furniture, and architectural elements. The use of light and shadow creates a sense of depth and atmosphere, while the color palette is dominated by various shades of blue and teal, complemented by warm golden tones from the sunlight and picture frames.

This work could be classified as part of the Realist or Academic tradition in painting, popular in the mid to late 19th century. It bears similarities to the works of artists like Jean-Léon Gérôme or Lawrence Alma-Tadema in its precise rendering of historical interiors and costumes, though the subject matter is more intimate and less exotic than many of their works.

It's getting late and I've been on this expedition for hours now. Deep inside, it doesn't feel as if I've been making any progress exploring this cave system at all. Maybe it's just the monotony of the whole situation, but it just feels as if I've gone in circles this entire time. Frankly I don't even know what I'm looking for on this mission, and so far I've seen nothing of note in this cave, living or not. I don't think it'd be too dangerous if I try and lay down before I pass out from exhaustion, I just need somewhere to sleep so I don't wake up with an aching back...
The passage I'm in has a bunch of old and dusty cobwebs, while it clearly isn't luxury, it'll keep me warm and comfortable for the rest of the night.

Tucking into one of the piles of webs, I start to hear skittering coming from up above me. Grabbing my flashlight and pointing it up towards the ceiling I spot what's making the noise. A huge black spider with eight long spindly legs, a spattering of red eyes and two huge fangs stares at me.
"Ooh, a human, wonderful, I haven't seen one of your kind in years!" she laughs, slowly beginning to lower herself from the roof and landing in front of me. Terrified for my life, I start to struggle as she approaches me, but the cobweb is too strong, and I feel myself slowly get stuck. "What's wrong? I just want to talk, human!" she laughs again, "What's with the hurry?"

Climbing onto me, she begins to slowly wrap a web around my legs, "That'll hold you in place..."
The hairs on her body start to tickle me, causing unpleasant sensations to run down my spine, "Now, human, what were you doing in my cave?" she asks with a sinister tone.

# Read the Excel file
excel_file = 'Ellucian Users - 01-08-2024.xlsx'
sheets = ['Campuslogic Users', 'Edunav users', 'Ellucian org users', 'Jira Server Users', 'Confluence Server Users']

# Function to convert DataFrame columns to lowercase
def convert_to_lowercase(df, columns):
    for col in columns:
        if col in df.columns:
            df[col] = df[col].str.lower()
    return df

# Function to convert 'Last, First' to 'First Last'
def convert_name_format(name):
    if ',' in name:
        parts = name.split(',', 1)
        if len(parts) == 2:
            last, first = parts
            return f"{first.strip()} {last.strip()}"
    return name

# Read and convert relevant columns to lowercase
dataframes = {}
for sheet in sheets:
    df = pd.read_excel(excel_file, sheet_name=sheet)
    df = convert_to_lowercase(df, ['Name', 'Email', 'Status'])
    
    # Special handling for 'Jira Server Users' and 'Confluence Server Users'
    if sheet in ['Jira Server Users', 'Confluence Server Users']:
        df['Name'] = df['Name'].apply(convert_name_format)
    
    dataframes[sheet] = df

def compare_data(source_sheet, target_sheets):
    results = []
    source_df = dataframes[source_sheet]
    
    for _, row in source_df.iterrows():
        if row['Status'] != 'active':  # Check if status is not 'active' (case insensitive)
            continue  # Skip this row
        
        source_name = row['Name']
        source_email = row['Email']
        found_tabs = []
        
        for target_sheet in target_sheets:
            target_df = dataframes[target_sheet]
            
            # Compare Name
            name_match = target_df[target_df['Name'] == source_name]
            if not name_match.empty:
                found_tabs.append(target_sheet)
            
            # Compare Email
            email_match = target_df[target_df['Email'] == source_email]
            if not email_match.empty:
                found_tabs.append(target_sheet)
        
        found_tabs = list(set(found_tabs))  # Remove duplicates
        
        if found_tabs:
            for tab in found_tabs:
                results.append([source_name, source_email, '', source_sheet, tab])
        else:
            results.append([source_name, source_email, '', source_sheet, 'Not Found'])
    
    return results

# Process Campuslogic Users
campuslogic_results = compare_data('Campuslogic Users', ['Edunav users', 'Ellucian org users', 'Jira Server Users', 'Confluence Server Users'])

# Process Edunav users
edunav_results = compare_data('Edunav users', ['Ellucian org users', 'Jira Server Users', 'Confluence Server Users'])

# Combine results
all_results = campuslogic_results + edunav_results

# Export to CSV
output_file = 'analysis_results.csv'
headers = ['Source Name', 'Source Email', 'Found Email', 'Source Tab', 'Found at Tab']

try:
    with open(output_file, 'w', newline='', encoding='utf-8') as csvfile:
        writer = csv.writer(csvfile)
        writer.writerow(headers)
        writer.writerows(all_results)
    print(f"Analysis complete. Results exported to {output_file}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"An error occurred while exporting to CSV: {e}")

colored faces, and 8 corner cubes with three colored faces. All blue cubes have been found. All cubes directly
left, right, above, and below the orange center cube have been found, along with the center cube. The green
corners have all been found, along with all green that borders yellow. For all orange cubes found, the opposite
face’s cubes have been found. The removed cube has two colors on its faces. What are they? Answer using a
comma separated list, with the colors ordered alphabetically.|||Consider the following sequence of transformations of a Tesseract (a four-dimensional hypercube):

Stage 0 (Initial Stage): A single four-dimensional hypercube.
Stage 1: Each face of the Tesseract is extruded outward by one unit along its normal vector in the four-dimensional space, creating smaller hypercubes at each original hypercube face.
Stage 2: Each of these new smaller hypercubes now rotates 45 degrees around its center in a plane defined by two of its four-dimensional axes.
Stage 3: Every edge of the resulting shape from Stage 2 extends outward by half a unit, each generating a new hypercube at its midpoint.
Stage X (Next Stage): ?
Determine the nature of the next transformation that the Tesseract undergoes in Stage X.

Options:
A. Each new hypercube is rotated 60 degrees around the original axes and then extended by one unit.

B. Each new hypercube undergoes a 45-degree rotation in the original plane and is then shrunk by half.

C. Each new hypercube is rotated 90 degrees around a new plane and then mirrored along a different plane.

D. Each new hypercube undergoes a 30-degree rotation around the original axes and is then reflected across the same plane.

E. Each new hypercube undergoes a 30-degree rotation in a new plane defined by two other four-dimensional axes and is then reflected across another plane.

F. Each new hypercube is rotated 15 degrees around a new plane and extended by one unit.
|||# Graph Coloring Problem

Problem: Find the chromatic number (the minimum number of colors needed for vertex coloring) of the following graph, and show one coloring method.

Vertices: A, B, C, D  
Edges: (A,B), (A,C), (B,D), (C,D)

I have a number of decks that went 7-0 on mtg arena that I got from 17lands website. I want you to tell me how I would go about training them into a model and making a bot that will help me draft on mtg arena. I don't want to include the drafts, only the decks. Also no meta information like mana cost, color, type etc. is to be taken into account. The only thing that should be taken into account is how often the cards appear with each other. That will be used for both drafting cards and building the final deck. The final deck will be 40 cards (including basic lands). It should consider that I can use basic lands (Forest, Mountain, Island, Plains, Swamp) freely and as many as I want so they should not be considered for picking (not to be confused with cards that simply have those words in their name and should be considered for picking).
During the drafting, the bot should present the cards to me sorted from the card with the highest number of co-occurences with the cards in the pool to the lowest. For the cards with no co-occurences, the number of total appearances in the decks should be considered instead along with the letter 'A' in front of the number.
Decks might have multiples of the same card (other than basic lands). That should be taken into account, both for total appearances and for co-occurences and both for the drafting phase and the deck building phase. (Example: CardA and CardB appear only in one deck together. CardA with one copy and CardB with four copies. The total co-occurrence number is 4. The number of appearances for CardB in the specific deck is 4 etc.)
After the draft is over, the bot should recommend me the best deck using the cards I drafted and the optimal amount and balance of basic lands (this should also be done algorithmically, either with co-occurrence matrix or some other machine learning method, so no arbitrary number and balance of basic lands).
The bot should have a UI and be 'always on top' so that it stays on top of the mtg arena window.
Give me a combined script.

This is an example deck (a single .txt file):
9 Plains
7 Mountain
1 Sundering Eruption
1 Aerie Auxiliary
1 Hexgold Slith
4 Mandibular Kite
3 Nyxborn Unicorn
2 Phelia, Exuberant Shepherd
2 Solstice Zealot
1 Voltstorm Angel
1 Wing It
1 Amped Raptor
1 Inventor's Axe
2 Smelted Chargebug
1 Unstable Amulet
1 Conduit Goblin
1 Scurry of Gremlins
1 Recruiter of the Guardr
